User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user account within the VishwaVerse platform.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user account.

roles.description: A list of roles assigned to the user.

createdAt.description: The date and time the user account was created.

updatedAt.description: The date and time the user account was last updated.

UserProfile.title: UserProfile
UserProfile.description: Represents the profile information for a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user profile.

bio.description: A short biography of the user.

skills.description: A list of the user's skills.

experience.description: A description of the user's experience.

achievements.description: A list of the user's achievements.

Admin.title: Admin
Admin.description: Represents an administrator account within the VishwaVerse platform. Granted via the roles_admin collection.

id.description: Unique identifier for the admin account (should match the user's UID).

grantedAt.description: Timestamp when the admin role was granted.

Developer.title: Developer
Developer.description: Represents a developer account. Granted via the roles_developer collection.

id.description: Unique identifier for the developer account (should match the user's UID).

grantedAt.description: Timestamp when the developer role was granted.

Customer.title: Customer
Customer.description: Represents a customer account. Granted via the roles_customer collection, typically after a purchase or project creation.

id.description: Unique identifier for the customer account (should match the user's UID).

firstPurchaseAt.description: Timestamp of the first purchase or project creation.

Project.title: Project
Project.description: Represents a client project, such as a website build, initiated through the quotation generator.

clientId.description: The ID of the user who owns this project.

serviceCategory.description: The category of the service requested (e.g., 'Web Development').

total.description: The total calculated price of the quotation.

quotationMarkdown.description: The AI-generated quotation in Markdown format.

status.description: The current status of the project.

progress.description: The completion percentage of the project (0-100).

updates.description: A list of progress updates for the project.

DesignOrder.title: DesignOrder
DesignOrder.description: Represents a design service order placed by a client.

id.description: Unique identifier for the design order.

clientId.description: The ID of the user who placed this order.

serviceType.description: The type of design service requested (e.g., 'Logo Design').

projectBrief.description: A detailed brief of the design project.

status.description: The current status of the design order.

DesignService.title: DesignService
DesignService.description: Represents a design service with multiple pricing tiers.

name.description: The name of the design service (e.g., 'Logo Design').

features.description: List of features included in this tier.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to support user authentication, profile management, and administrative roles, focusing on security, scalability, and debuggability. It incorporates key principles such as Authorization Independence, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and Structural Segregation to streamline security rules and maintain data integrity.

*   **Authorization Independence:** The `users/{userId}` collection includes the `profileId` field. While seemingly creating a `get()` dependency, the intended use-case is to simply store the ID. Access to `/users/{userId}/profile` is granted via path-based ownership, eliminating the need for `get()` calls in security rules.
*   **Structural Segregation:** User profiles and roles (admin, developer, customer) are stored in separate collections (`userProfiles`, `roles_admin`, `roles_developer`, `roles_customer`), ensuring different security postures for each. This segregation simplifies rules and avoids mixing data with varying access requirements.
*   **DBAC:** Roles are managed through their respective `roles_*` collections. The existence of a document for a user in any of these collections grants the corresponding privileges, enabling simple existence-based security rules.
*   **QAPs:** `list` operations are secured by enforcing ownership and role-based access controls. Path-based ownership (`users/{userId}`) allows listing only resources owned by the authenticated user. Role checks in the `roles_*` collections authorize administrative `list` operations.

This structure facilitates secure and efficient data access while adhering to core design principles, minimizing complexity and maximizing debuggability.
